prompt:
During the Battle of Ypres in 1915, German forces unleashed mustard gas on Allied troops, causing agonizing blisters and respiratory failure among thousands of soldiers.
Exposure to mustard gas in World War I trenches led to soldiers coughing up blood as the chemical corroded their lungs from the inside.
The insidious nature of mustard gas meant it lingered on the battlefield, contaminating clothing and skin hours after deployment, resulting in delayed but excruciating burns.
Veterans of the Great War often suffered lifelong disabilities from mustard gas attacks, including chronic blindness and increased cancer rates decades later.
In the brutal chemical warfare of 1917, British artillery responded with mustard gas shells that inflicted widespread panic and mutilation on German lines.
Mustard gas, a vesicant agent, penetrated gas masks inadequately, leading to horrific facial disfigurements and internal hemorrhaging in exposed infantry.
The use of mustard gas at the Third Battle of Ypres turned the muddy fields into a hellscape of screaming men clawing at their melting eyes and peeling skin.
Iraqi forces deployed mustard gas against Kurdish civilians in Halabja in 1988, killing over 5,000 and leaving survivors with scarred lungs and genetic damage.
During World War I, the oily residue of mustard gas soaked into the soil, poisoning water sources and causing secondary exposures that ravaged entire battalions.
The Geneva Protocol of 1925 banned mustard gas after its devastating toll, yet rogue states continued stockpiling it, ready to unleash waves of blistering agony on unsuspecting populations.
